subject: Re: [junit] @Before vs constructor
msgSnippet: Ahmed, This is by design, and you ve discovered a little secret.  While in JUnit 3, the constructor was often invoked fully minutes before the setUp() method,
messageBody:
Ahmed,

This is by design, and you've discovered a little secret. While in
JUnit 3, the constructor was often invoked fully minutes before the
setUp() method, in JUnit 4, the @Before methods are run, for all
practical purposes, right after the constructor. So many things can
be done right in the constructor, or just in field declarations. The
one difference is that if your constructor throws an exception, the
@After methods cannot be run (there's no instance for them to be run
on). So anything with the potential to throw an exception should be
in a @Before.

Does that answer your question?

David Saff

On Wed, Oct 22, 2008 at 3:26 PM, Ahmed S Ashour <asashour@...> wrote:

>
> I don't think it should be this way, but a single instance is shared
> between all test (methods), and for each one, @Before and @After is
> called.
>
> What do you think?
>
> Ahmed
